# Intonation {.transition}

## What is intonation?

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}

::: {.fragment .fade-up}
Modulation of [fundamental frequency]{.emph} (F0), perceived as [pitch]{.emph}
:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](assets/vocal_folds_vibrating.gif)
:::

::::

## Continuous signal, discrete perception {.smaller}

![](assets/continuous_to_discrete.bmp){width="900" height="500"}

Our [goal]{.emph} is to describe the F0 contour with the tonal inventory available to us.

We care about the [phonological contrasts]{.emph} and the [phonetic implementations]{.emph}

## What discrete events are we working with?

::: {.fragment .fade-up}
::: {.fragment .semi-fade-out}
[pitch accents]{.emph} are anchored to [stressed syllables]{.emph}
:::
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-up}
::: {.fragment .semi-fade-out}
[boundary tones]{.emph} are anchored to [phrase boundaries]{.emph}
:::
:::

## Castilian Spanish tonal inventory

| Pitch accents  | iP boundary tones| IP boundary tones |
|:---------------|:-----------------|:------------------|
| H*             | L-               | L%                |            
| L*             | !H-              | !H%               |            
| L+H*           | H-               | H%                |            
| L+¡H*          | HL-              | HL%               |            
| L+<H*          | LH-              | LH%               |            
| L*+H           |                  | L!H%              |            
| H+L*           | LHL-             | LHL%              |        

::: notes
Mention that the star indicates which tone is mainly aligned with stressed syllable.
:::

# Prediction {.transition}

## Prediction in the L1

::: {.fragment}
Humans constantly [predict]{.emph} non-linguistic [@bar2007proactive; @lee2003hierarchical] and [linguistic]{.emph} information [@van2012prediction; @altmann1999incremental]
:::

::: {.fragment}
Extant research suggests that intonational information is [processed in real-time]{.emph} [@grodner2010some; @kamide2003time; @crocker2010computational; @levy2008expectation]
:::

## Prediction in the L1 {.smaller}

::: {.fragment}
Homophones can be distinguished based on a "contradictory" contour [@esteve2020empathy]
:::

::: {.fragment}
![](assets/esteve2020empathy_contours.bmp)
:::

## But not all cues are weighted equally

::: {.fragment}
L1 German and L1 English speakers completed a series of on-line [mouse-tracking]{.emph} studies
:::

::: {.fragment}
Do speakers use [early pitch accents]{.emph} to predict if a referent downstream is given or contrastive?
:::

::: {.fragment}
German speakers ❌

English speakers ✔️
:::

::: footer
@roettger2021positional
:::

## But not all cues are weighted equally

::: {.incremental}
- perceivers [don't use]{.emph} prenuclear pitch accents to infer speaker intentions?
- depends on [type]{.emph} of prenuclear pitch accent? e.g., unmarked rise vs salient rise-fall
- [delayed]{.emph} semantic integration? i.e., prosodic prominence can only be judged relative to its environment
:::

::: footer
@roettger2021positional
:::

## In sum...

It's [not a given]{.emph} that L1 Spanish speakers will integrate early intonational cues to [predict]{.emph} sentence type!


## Prediction in the L2


::: {.fragment}
L1 German L2 English [CEFR B2 or above; @councilofeurope2001cefr] learners [predict]{.emph} referent based on contrastive pitch accent [in L1]{.emph}, but [not in L2]{.emph} for the same sound-to-meaning prediction [@foltz2021using]
:::

::: {.fragment}
In contrast, @klassen2015second found that L1 Spanish L2 English learners [predict]{.emph} referent based on contrastive pitch accent [in L2]{.emph}
:::

::: {.fragment}
The cues matched in the L1 and L2 in both studies... so why the difference?
:::

::: {.fragment}
The Spanish-English bilinguals had [more time]{.emph} to predict in the task?
:::

## Comparing English and Spanish sentence modality cues

+-------------------------------+---------------------------+------------------------------+
| Cue                           | Spanish                   | English                      |
+===============================+===========================+==============================+
| First peak height             | higher = interrogatives   | associated with              |
|                               | lower = declaratives      | emphasis [@chen2003reaction] |
|                               |                           |                              |
+-------------------------------+---------------------------+------------------------------+
| Presence/absence of medial    | absence = interrogative   | no correlates                |
| pitch accent                  | presence = declarative    |                              |
+-------------------------------+---------------------------+------------------------------+

: {tbl-colwidths="[50,75,75]"}

## So what do we expect?

L2 speakers [can]{.emph} predict when cues match, but there's a [delay]{.emph}

Here, no cues match

# Research questions {.transition}

:::: {.r-fit-text}

::: {.incremental}

1. Is the first F0 peak height used to predict sentence modality?

2. Is the presence or absence of a medial pitch accent used to predict sentence modality?

3. Do L1 English L2 Spanish speakers recruit either first F0 peak height or the presence/absence of a medial pitch accent to predict sentence modality?

4. Do prediction capabilities depend on amount of time (operationalized here as sentence length) a learner has to process a given cue?

:::

::::

# Methodology {.transition}

## Participants 

::: {.incremental}

- 25 L1 Madrid Spanish speakers
- 100 L1 UK English L2 Spanish late learners (B2 or higher)
  - primarily exposed to Spain Spanish
  - range of proficiencies from B1 to B2
  - range of exposures

:::
